All right, so the first
step to making tamales

is making tamale filling,
three different iterations
of which I'll be demonstrating.
First up, some braised beef.

I got a nice four or five
pound chuck roast here

that I'm going to liberally
season with kosher salt,
plop into my favorite Dutch oven and add
two beef bullion cubes, one large onion,

peeled and quartered, just
kinda tuck it in there
or put it under the roast if you have to.

A half a dozen whole,
peeled cloves of garlic

and one tablespoon of oregano,
preferably Mexican oregano.
And that's it,

we're just gonna put enough
water in the Dutch oven
to almost cover the roast,

and braise in a 275
degree Fahrenheit oven,

preferably with convection
for three to four hours,

taking it out and giving
it a flip once or twice
during cooking.

You know it's done when
it's deeply browned
and super-duper tender.
While that's braising, we're gonna make
an accompanying chili paste.

I got four ancho, four pasilla
and six guajillo chiles,
all of which I'm going to deseed, devein
and tear into one-inch pieces.

Place them into a medium
saucepan and dry roast them

or until fragrant but not smoking.

Then we're quenching these with
just enough water to cover,

adding four or five cloves of
garlic and half a small onion,
roughly chopped.

Then we're covering, bringing
to a boil and simmering

for 15 minutes before pureeing
in a high powered blender

with just enough cooking
liquid to make it thick
but still pourable.

After a few hours, once
the beef is out the oven

and it shows no resistance when
stabbed with a paring knife,

we're gonna retrieve it
from the braising liquid,
separate the fat and meat, shred the meat

and toss it with a little
bit of the chili paste,

seasoning to taste with
a pinch of kosher salt

and a few twists of freshly
ground black pepper.

And there you have it,
braised beef for tamales.
Now let's take a look at a chicken option.

Chicken for tamales is usually
poached and then sauced.

My favorite way to poach chicken
for virtually any context

is to butterfly it, bring
a couple quarts of water

to a boil, kill the
heat, drop in the chicken

and cover it up, letting
the carry over heat
slowly and gently bring the chicken up

to 155 degrees Fahrenheit
at its thickest point,
which depending on the amount of chicken
and the amount of water should take
between 12 to 18 minutes.

This is almost like a
super quick, super easy,

sous vide method that keeps
the chicken moist and tender.

Shred it up and let it
cool, and then to sauce it,

we're gonna make a sort
of quick salsa verde.

I have here, nine
tomatillos, two jalapenos

and one poblano pepper, which
I'm going to throw under

a high-powered broiler
for two to five minutes
until we get some nice color on there,

cover with aluminum foil and
allow to steam for 10 minutes,

so as we can easily
remove everybody's skin
and the stems and seeds of the peppers.
Dump all these guys into your blender,

along with half a small
onion, roughly chopped,

two cloves of chopped garlic,
a pinch of kosher salt,

a few twists of freshly
ground black pepper
and one single leaf of, all right fine,

a bunch of cilantro,
stems, leaves, the works.

Blend until pretty
smooth, but it still has
a good chunk to it, then once both it

and the chicken have cooled,
go ahead and let them
get to know each other.

You can do this same-day or
cover in the fridge overnight
to really let the flavors meld.
Now, you might be asking yourself,

in, just throw it away?"

And the answer is no,
we're gonna strain it

and 24 to 26 ounces of very hot water.

is obviously gonna bring

You could also use the

Add enough water so that
when you mix it together,
it forms a crumbly, but shapeable dough,

during which time we're

14 ounces of lard, to be precise.

We're beating the lard together
with two teaspoons each

kosher salt and baking

Then all we have to do is make a huge mess
and regret everything.
Then add the crumbly masa harina dough,

Just like all things in

we just basically need

Once you get it nice and smooth and soft,

homogenous spreadable paste.

Now, there are such a
thing as dessert tamales,
and they're very easy to make.

Simply add five tablespoons
of granulated sugar
to your completed dough.

One teaspoon vanilla extract,
one teaspoon cinnamon,
and some fruit.

nuts, anything you want.

Just mix her up until

and the dough is a lovely shade of pink.

Now, the last thing we gotta
do is soak some corn husks.

You can either soak them
in water for 24 hours
or soak them in hot water for three hours.

Once soaked, we're gonna
dry them off a little bit,
but mostly we're gonna sort them,

the widest and most intact
husks being ideal for tamales.
The misshapen or broken ones
being perfect for tearing into ties.

At long last, we're finally
ready to get rolling.

To fill the tamales, you
want to smear between a third

to a half a cup of the
tamale dough onto the center

of the upper half of the
husk into a rectangle

about six by four inches
and a quarter inch thick.

Place a nice little
landing strip of filling

down the center of the
dough and use the husk

to wrap the dough up
and around the filling.

Make sure that the dough
completely envelops the filling
before folding the corn husk shut.

You can squeeze the bottom a

fold up the bottom of the husk and tie it
using a length of torn husk.

And there you have it,
a braised beef tamale,
pretty as you please.

and really the only difference

so that it's the same size

Now my ultimate tamale

a sort of Tom Sawyer move.

Act like you're having

and convince your friends

We just want to stack them

cover the tamales with

Place the basket over an inch of water

Then, letting them rest in the

You know that they're done

springy texture and they come
